qas.question: Why are there multiple variations of texts before the advent of the printing press?
Are printed editions immune to variation?

answers.text: not immune to introducing variations from an author's autograph

qas.question: How do differences in works arise when using a printing press?

answers.text: a compositor or a printing shop may read or typeset a work in a way that differs from the autograph

qas.question: An edited text compiled through many sources is known as what?
How did they copy literature before they did it by hand?
How did they copy literature after mechanical printing?

plausible_answers.text: reconstruction of the lost original is often aided by a selection of readings taken from many sources

qas.question: How do printing presses provide identical copies?

plausible_answers.text: text that draws from multiple sources is said to be eclectic

qas.question: Why do textual critics prefer to use multiple sources?

context: Before <b4_0>mechanical printing<b4_0/>, <a0_0>literature was copied <b5_0>by hand<b5_0/><a0_0/>, and many variations were introduced by copyists. The age of printing made the scribal profession effectively redundant. Printed editions, while less susceptible to the proliferation of variations likely to arise during manual transmission, are nonetheless <a1_0>not immune to introducing variations from an author's autograph<a1_0/>. Instead of a scribe miscopying his source, <a2_0>a compositor or a printing shop may read or typeset a work in a way that differs from the autograph<a2_0/>. Since each scribe or printer commits different errors, <b6_0>reconstruction of the lost original is often aided by a selection of readings taken from many sources<b6_0/>. An edited <b7_0>text that draws from multiple sources is said to be <a3_0>eclectic<b7_0/>.<a3_0/> In contrast to this approach, some textual critics prefer to identify the single best surviving text, and not to combine readings from multiple sources.
